citations.narrative:
***Disposition records show that 8 small birds disappeared from the “center flight” aviary in the past 3 months: Four violet
backed starlings (18A026, 19A022, 20370, 23A075), two long-tailed paradise-whydah (18A035, 18A032), one silver-
beaked tanager (24A011), and one troupial (21A032).
Facility staff searched for the birds for but did not find them. Facility staff stated that the most likely cause of the birds’
disappearance is predation by rodents, and at the time of inspection there were rodent droppings in some non-public
areas within the building. The Center Flight aviary is a large indoor aviary which is has two entrances made of hanging
chain link, in addition to the solid exterior doors of the building.
***Facility staff stated that one North American ruddy duck recently disappeared, and that the bird was likely lost to
predation (most likely racoons). The facility searched for the bird thoroughly but could not find it. The bird had been living
in the “Teton Marsh Exhibit”, which contains a pond and natural marshy areas, and also houses a variety of waterfowl.
The back walls of the enclosure are six-foot-tall chain link, and the front of the enclosure is an elevated public walkway
bordered by an approximately 4-foot tall wire and wooden fence. The bird was flight restricted (pinioned). The facility has
a predator control program in place and has undertaken measures to prevent additional predation near this exhibit such
as providing additional vegetation in the exhibit.
Birds that are not effectively contained in their enclosures and protected from predators may suffer from stress, injuries, or
death.
Correct by ensuring that bird enclosures are maintained in good repair, protect the birds from injury, contain the birds, and
restrict other animals from entering who may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. Correct by 4/28/24.

No attendant was present in the petting zoo area. There are three enclosures (housing zebu, goats, and sheep
respectively) that are constructed with an approximately 4-foot-tall wooden fence with horizontal slats separates the
viewing public from the animals; and members of the public are not prevented from petting or otherwise reaching over or
through the fence to touch the animals. There is no signage in the area telling members of the public not to touch the
animals, and facility representatives agreed that members of the public are allowed to pet the animals over and through
the wooden fence.
Unsupervised contact between animals and the public may result in stress or injury to animals or members of the public.
Correct by 4/15/24 by ensuring that a responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant is
present at all times during periods of public contact.

The ozone delivery system for the water in the enclosure housing California Sea Lions was not fully operational from
1/1/24 to 2/6/24. Test results from four consecutive coliform bacterial tests of the water in the enclosure housing the
California Sea Lions showed levels that were “>2420 MPN per 100mL”. The dates of the tests were 1/9/24, 1/11/24,
1/23/24, and 2/6/24. Tests were not performed the week of 1/17/24 (due to a winter ice storm which prohibited submission
of samples to the lab). Although corrective actions were undertaken following the test results when coliforms exceeded
1000 MPN per 100 mL, the overall coliform test results not fall below 1000 MPN per 100mL between 1/2/2024 and 2/9/24.
Water quality is important for maintaining marine mammal health. High levels of coliform bacteria may indicate poor water
quality which could be harmful to animal health.
Correct by 3/28/24 by maintaining water quality in accordance with the Animal Welfare Act regulations. At the time of the
inspection, the facility had already completed major renovations to their water quality systems.

Coliform testing was not conducted from December 20, 2024 to January 3, 2024 (13 days). Facility staff stated that the
commercial laboratory where this testing is performed was not open during this time period.
Weekly coliform testing of marine mammal water is important for ensuring that water quality is in compliance with the
Animal Welfare Act (AWA) regulations and is not harmful to the animals.
Correct by 3/28/24 by ensuring that marine mammal water is tested as required by the AWA regulations, to include
weekly testing for coliform bacteria.

The facility self-reported that on January 28th, 2024, some Naked Mole Rats (NMRs) died as a result of accidental
overheating in their enclosure. The NMR colony enclosure is a collection of boxes and tubes with ventilation openings on
the tops of the boxes. The heater in the building where the animals are housed (the nocturnal building) had stopped
working prior to the incident, so the facility was using a new temporary heater to keep the building warm. The temporary
duct bringing warm air into the building was located near the NMR enclosure. Although facility staff had placed 3
temperature monitors within the building, there were no temperature monitors in the NMR enclosure. Upon discovering
the issue, the facility immediately took corrective actions to provide care for the remaining animals and to control the
temperature of the building. Unfortunately, 15 out of 24 adult NMRs passed away and necropsy results showed signs of
hyperthermia (abnormally high body temperature). At the time of the incident, the temperature was measured by facility
staff and was found to be 102 degrees Fahrenheit on the surface of the glass at the front of the enclosure and 94 degrees
Fahrenheit within the animal enclosure. The facility also added additional temperature monitors throughout the building
including in the NMR enclosure.
Indoor enclosures that are not adequately heated and/or cooled may cause discomfort or adverse health effects for the
animals within.
Correct by 3/28/24 by ensuring that temperatures in indoor housing facility are sufficiently regulated by heating or cooling
to protect animals from temperature extremes and to provide for animal health and comfort. Corrected prior to the
inspection.

There is evidence of widespread rodent activity in the giraffe and rhino holding areas. Although facility staff diligently clean
these facilities on a daily basis, there was a large accumulation of rodent droppings on top of some heating ducts in the
giraffe barn, as well as a smaller amount of droppings in some walkways. In the rhino barn, there are rodent droppings
under some furniture/equipment and on some horizontal shelves/beams. There was also a large amount of small plastic
shavings beneath a large hard plastic toy which an employee stated was due to rodents chewing on the toy.
Pests including rodents can spread disease and may contaminate enclosures.
Correct by 4/28/24 by maintaining a safe and effective program to control insects, ectoparasites, rodents, and other pests
so as to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
There is evidence of widespread rodent activity in the tropical bird aviary, especially behind the gunite walls that make up
the “Center Flight” aviary. In this area there is an excessive accumulation of rodent droppings on the floors and horizontal
structures. On 2/24/24, one female Pompadour cotinga bird (20A001) and one male white-tailed trogon/green backed
trogon (23528) were missing and presumed dead after feathers and the cotinga’s leg band were found in nest box 14 in
the “Center Flight” aviary. Additionally, 8 small birds from the center flight aviary have gone missing over the past 3
months.
Pests including rodents can spread disease, contaminate enclosures, and may injure or predate birds.
Correct by 4/28/24 by maintaining a safe and effective program to control insects, ectoparasites, rodents, and other pests
so as to promote the health and well-being of the birds and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.150(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
***Disposition records show that 8 small birds disappeared from the “center flight” aviary in the past 3 months: Four violet 
backed starlings (18A026, 19A022, 20370, 23A075), two long-tailed paradise-whydah (18A035, 18A032), one silver-
beaked tanager (24A011), and one troupial (21A032).  
Facility staff searched for the birds for but did not find them. Facility staff stated that the most likely cause of the birds’ 
disappearance is predation by rodents, and at the time of inspection there were rodent droppings in some non-public 
areas within the building. The Center Flight aviary is a large indoor aviary which is has two entrances made of hanging 
chain link, in addition to the solid exterior doors of the building.  
***Facility staff stated that one North American ruddy duck recently disappeared, and that the bird was likely lost to 
predation (most likely racoons). The facility searched for the bird thoroughly but could not find it. The bird had been living 
in the “Teton Marsh Exhibit”, which contains a pond and natural marshy areas, and also houses a variety of waterfowl. 
The back walls of the enclosure are six-foot-tall chain link, and the front of the enclosure is an elevated public walkway

as providing additional vegetation in the exhibit.  
Birds that are not effectively contained in their enclosures and protected from predators may suffer from stress, injuries, or 
death.  
Correct by ensuring that bird enclosures are maintained in good repair, protect the birds from injury, contain the birds, and 
restrict other animals from entering who may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. Correct by 4/28/24. 
2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
No attendant was present in the petting zoo area. There are three enclosures (housing zebu, goats, and sheep 
respectively) that are constructed with an approximately 4-foot-tall wooden fence with horizontal slats separates the 
viewing public from the animals; and members of the public are not prevented from petting or otherwise reaching over or 
through the fence to touch the animals. There is no signage in the area telling members of the public not to touch the 
animals, and facility representatives agreed that members of the public are allowed to pet the animals over and through 
the wooden fence.  
Unsupervised contact between animals and the public may result in stress or injury to animals or members of the public.

Correct by 4/15/24 by ensuring that a responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant is 
present at all times during periods of public contact. 
3.106(b)(1) 
   
Water quality. 
The ozone delivery system for the water in the enclosure housing California Sea Lions was not fully operational from 
1/1/24 to 2/6/24. Test results from four consecutive coliform bacterial tests of the water in the enclosure housing the 
California Sea Lions showed levels that were “>2420 MPN per 100mL”. The dates of the tests were 1/9/24, 1/11/24, 
1/23/24, and 2/6/24. Tests were not performed the week of 1/17/24 (due to a winter ice storm which prohibited submission 
of samples to the lab). Although corrective actions were undertaken following the test results when coliforms exceeded 
1000 MPN per 100 mL, the overall coliform test results not fall below 1000 MPN per 100mL between 1/2/2024 and 2/9/24.  
Water quality is important for maintaining marine mammal health. High levels of coliform bacteria may indicate poor water 
quality which could be harmful to animal health.  
Correct by 3/28/24 by maintaining water quality in accordance with the Animal Welfare Act regulations. At the time of the 
inspection, the facility had already completed major renovations to their water quality systems. 
3.106(b)(3) 
   
Water quality. 
Coliform testing was not conducted from December 20, 2024 to January 3, 2024 (13 days). Facility staff stated that the 
commercial laboratory where this testing is performed was not open during this time period.  
Weekly coliform testing of marine mammal water is important for ensuring that water quality is in compliance with the 
Animal Welfare Act (AWA) regulations and is not harmful to the animals.  
Correct by 3/28/24 by ensuring that marine mammal water is tested as required by the AWA regulations, to include 
weekly testing for coliform bacteria. 
3.126(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, indoor. 
The facility self-reported that on January 28th, 2024, some Naked Mole Rats (NMRs) died as a result of accidental 
overheating in their enclosure. The NMR colony enclosure is a collection of boxes and tubes with ventilation openings on 
the tops of the boxes. The heater in the building where the animals are housed (the nocturnal building) had stopped

animals within.

Correct by 3/28/24 by ensuring that temperatures in indoor housing facility are sufficiently regulated by heating or cooling 
to protect animals from temperature extremes and to provide for animal health and comfort. Corrected prior to the 
inspection. 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
There is evidence of widespread rodent activity in the giraffe and rhino holding areas. Although facility staff diligently clean 
these facilities on a daily basis, there was a large accumulation of rodent droppings on top of some heating ducts in the 
giraffe barn, as well as a smaller amount of droppings in some walkways. In the rhino barn, there are rodent droppings

Correct by 4/28/24 by maintaining a safe and effective program to control insects, ectoparasites, rodents, and other pests 
so as to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas. 
3.158(d)  Critical
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
There is evidence of widespread rodent activity in the tropical bird aviary, especially behind the gunite walls that make up 
the “Center Flight” aviary. In this area there is an excessive accumulation of rodent droppings on the floors and horizontal 
structures. On 2/24/24, one female Pompadour cotinga bird (20A001) and one male white-tailed trogon/green backed

months.  
Pests including rodents can spread disease, contaminate enclosures, and may injure or predate birds.  
Correct by 4/28/24 by maintaining a safe and effective program to control insects, ectoparasites, rodents, and other pests 
so as to promote the health and well-being of the birds and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
